item.title: Effects of Empagliflozin on Uric Acid and Gout in CKD - DocWire News
item.description:
Effects of Empagliflozin on Uric Acid and Gout in CKD

Publication Date: N/A Source: Nephrology Dialysis Transplantation

This article discusses the findings of researchers exploring the effects of SGLT2 inhibition on uric acid levels and gout incidence in chronic kidney disease patients, based on data from the EMPA-KIDNEY trial.

  • Study involved 6,609 patients with CKD randomized to empagliflozin or placebo over two years.
  • Mean serum uric acid concentration was reduced by 25.6 µmol/L in the empagliflozin group.
  • No significant reduction in gout events compared to placebo was observed.
  • Effects were more pronounced in non-diabetic patients and those with higher eGFR.
“SGLT2 inhibition reduces serum uric acid in patients with CKD with larger effects at higher eGFR and in the absence of diabetes. However, the effect on uric acid is modest and did not translate into reduced risk of gout in EMPA-KIDNEY.”

Despite reducing uric acid levels, empagliflozin does not significantly decrease the risk of gout among CKD patients.

item.title: Frustrated with low income? Study says this habit may be the unseen culprit - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Smoking May Be Impacting Your Income, Study Finds

Date: Jan 14, 2025 | Source: Hindustan Times

A new study published in the journal Nicotine & Tobacco Research highlights the hidden economic costs of smoking, revealing a correlation between smoking habits and lower earnings, particularly among less educated individuals.

  • The study examined data from 3,596 participants in Finland.
  • Each 1-pack-year increase in smoking is associated with a 1.8% decrease in earnings.
  • Participants who reduced their smoking by five pack-years could see a potential 9% increase in earnings.
  • The findings suggest that smoking disproportionately affects younger, less educated workers.
  • There is less impact noticed on older workers.
“Smoking leads to low income, especially for young people from low educational backgrounds, as they may be in jobs that require physical work.”

In conclusion, while smoking has well-documented health risks, this study adds an economic perspective to the dangers of smoking, revealing its potential to adversely affect income levels.

item.title: Effective ways to relieve lower back pain during periods - The Indian Express
item.description:
Effective Ways to Relieve Lower Back Pain During Periods

Published on: Unknown date Source: The Indian Express

This article discusses various methods to alleviate lower back pain often experienced during menstruation. It suggests exercises, dietary adjustments, and lifestyle changes that can help.

  • Regular exercise improves flexibility and strengthens core muscles, reducing lower back pain.
  • Incorporating deep breathing techniques, meditation, and mild stretches can relieve tension and discomfort.
  • Yoga poses such as Ushtrasana and Bhujangasana strengthen lower back muscles and mitigate pain.
  • Reducing caffeine and salty meals can help prevent bloating that exacerbates back pain.
  • A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and omega-3 fatty acids can lower inflammation.
  • Wearing loose-fitting clothing can enhance comfort and reduce strain during periods.
"Regular exercise helps to increase flexibility and strengthen core muscles, which can greatly lessen lower back pain during menstruation."

This article provides practical solutions for managing lower back pain during menstruation, emphasizing the importance of physical activity and dietary choices for overall comfort.

item.title: Fibre in diet can reduce risk of gut infections: 6 ways to add more fibre in meals - The Times of India
item.description:
Fibre in diet can reduce risk of gut infections: 6 ways to add more fibre in meals

Publication Date: October 2023

Source: Health Wellness Journal

Fibre is essential for digestive health, and a diet high in fibre can significantly lower the risk of gut infections. Here are six effective ways to incorporate more fibre into meals.

  • Include fruits and vegetables in every meal.
  • Opt for whole grain products over refined grains.
  • Add legumes such as beans and lentils to dishes.
  • Snacks on nuts and seeds instead of processed foods.
  • Incorporate more high-fibre cereals into breakfast.
  • Experiment with fibre-rich recipes.
"A diet rich in fibre is crucial for maintaining gut health and preventing infections," says a nutrition expert.

In conclusion, enhancing your diet with more fibre can lead to better gut health and overall well-being.

item.title: Obese children face heightened risk of relapse post-cancer diagnosis - The Jerusalem Post
item.description:
Obese Children Face Increased Risk of Cancer Relapse and Mortality

Date: January 14, 2025 Source: Jpost

Obesity in children diagnosed with cancer poses significant health risks, highlighting the importance of managing obesity to improve cancer outcomes.

  • Study conducted by researchers at Montreal's Sainte-Justine Hospital.
  • Data analyzed from the Cancer in Young People in Canada database (2001-2020).
  • 10.5% of 11,291 children with cancer were classified as obese.
  • Obese children had lower rates of 5-year event-free survival (77.5% vs 79.6%) and overall survival (83.0% vs 85.9%).
  • Obesity linked to a 16% increased risk of cancer relapse and a 29% increased risk of death.
  • Most pronounced effects observed in patients with acute lymphoblastic leukemia and brain tumors.
“Our study highlights the negative impact of obesity among all types of childhood cancers. It provides the rationale to evaluate different strategies to mitigate the adverse risk of obesity on cancer outcomes in future trials,” said co-senior author Thai Hoa Tran, MD.

This study underscores the urgent need to address childhood obesity, which can have serious health implications for affected children.

item.title: Eyes give these early symptoms of cancer and diabetes: Know more - Onmanorama
item.description:
Eyes Give These Early Symptoms of Cancer and Diabetes: Know More

Published: January 14, 2025

The article discusses how the eyes can reveal early signs of serious health conditions such as diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and certain cancer types. It emphasizes the importance of eye health in diagnosing these diseases early.

  • Poets claim eyes convey emotions, but they can also show early disease signs.
  • 25% of type 1 and 40% of type 2 diabetic patients may have eye defects.
  • High blood pressure symptoms visible in the eyes include prominent blood vessels.
  • High cholesterol can lead to health issues in the eye like Hollenhorst plague.
  • Retinoblastoma, affecting eyes, can spread to other organs.
  • Eyes offer clues for serious ailments like brain tumors.
  • Symptoms like unusual eye movements warrant immediate medical attention.
“These symptoms in the eyes may be signs of underlying diseases that should not be ignored.”

In conclusion, maintaining eye health is crucial for early diagnosis of severe health issues. Regular eye checks can help identify potential health risks before they become critical.

item.title: Indonesia launches livestock vaccinations as foot and mouth disease spreads - Deccan Herald
item.description:
Indonesia Launches Livestock Vaccination to Combat Foot and Mouth Disease Outbreak

Published: 14 January 2025, Source: Deccan Herald

Indonesia has initiated a vaccination program to control an outbreak of foot and mouth disease affecting 11 provinces and resulting in thousands of infected livestock.

  • The outbreak has led to 338 livestock deaths and 14,630 infections since the first case was reported in December.
  • The vaccination strategy aims to immunize healthy animals, according to Imron Suandy, the director of animal health.
  • Factors for the outbreak include unvaccinated livestock and extreme weather influencing animal immunity.
  • The government has allocated 4 million doses of vaccines focusing on high-case areas, particularly on Java island.
  • Last year, more than 455,000 livestock were infected, resulting in significant fatalities and slaughtering.
  • The government is encouraging the import of breeding cows to support future food supply initiatives.
“Our strategy is through livestock vaccination of healthy animals to provide immunity against the disease.” - Imron Suandy

This vaccination effort is critical to control the spread of the disease and protect the livestock sector in Indonesia, which is vital to the country's economy and food supply.

item.title: Genetics, brain development, and mental health shape teen eating - News-Medical.Net
item.description:
Genetics and Brain Development Impact Teen Eating Habits

Published on: October 2023
Source: Nature Mental Health

Recent research finds a correlation between genetic predisposition, brain maturation, and eating disorders in adolescents, emphasizing the need for early intervention.

  • Study explores the neurobiological links of eating behaviors to genetics and psychopathology.
  • Key eating behaviors identified: cognitive restraint, emotional eating, and uncontrolled eating.
  • Longitudinal study involved 996 participants in the IMAGEN project across Europe.
  • Three eating behavior clusters were found: healthy eaters, restrictive eaters, and emotional/uncontrolled eaters.
  • Restrictive and emotional eaters reported higher rates of dieting and binge eating.
"Adolescents with unhealthy eating patterns were found to have higher body mass index and polygenic scores, indicating genetic predisposition to obesity."

The findings highlight the intricate interplay between genetics, brain development, and mental health in affecting eating patterns among teenagers.

item.title: Move body and mind: five exercises to improve mental health, from twists to lunges - The Guardian
item.description:
Five Simple Exercises to Boost Mental Health

Publication Date: October 2023

Source: The Guardian

Exercise is recognized for its psychological benefits, yet many struggle to maintain a routine. This article outlines five fundamental exercises that encourage not only physical fitness but also improved mental health.

  • Squats: Helps in getting comfortable with discomfort.
  • Lunges: Aids in overcoming stuckness and fear of movement.
  • Twists: Encourages fluidity and flow in movement.
  • Hinge exercises: Promotes self-ownership and upright posture.
  • Push and Pull movements: Essential for building strength and resilience.
“The mood improvements that can come with 30-45 minutes of exercise are more attainable than the six-packs and beach bodies advertised by many gym chains.”

Incorporating these exercises into daily practice can lead to lasting changes in both physical and mental health.

item.title: How Does Climate Change Affect Microplastic Degradation? - AZoM
item.description:
How Does Climate Change Affect Microplastic Degradation?

Publication Date: N/A | Source: AZoM

The article discusses how climate change affects the degradation of microplastics, emphasizing the increasing presence of these pollutants due to poor plastic waste management and rising global plastic production rates.

  • Microplastics are categorized into primary and secondary types, with the latter forming from larger plastics through various processes.
  • Rising temperatures and climate change accelerate microplastic breakdown and increase their prevalence in ecosystems.
  • Extreme weather events contribute to the movement and fragmentation of plastic debris, leading to more microplastics entering the environment.
  • Microbial activity related to temperature variations significantly influences plastic degradation efficiency.
  • Future research is needed to better understand how climate variables affect microplastics and to develop effective mitigation strategies.

"Once in aquatic ecosystems, microplastics tend to remain and accumulate, resulting in a growing pervasiveness and steady increase in microplastic concentrations"
— Nathanial Banks, Co-Founder and CTO, PolyGone Systems.

Addressing microplastic pollution is critical as climate change continues to alter environments and increase the distribution of these pollutants.

item.title: Too hot or too cold? Here's why your home’s temperature could be hurting your focus, brain health - Hindustan Times
item.description:
How Home Temperature Affects Focus and Brain Health in Older Adults

Publication Date: December 3, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

This article discusses a study revealing the impact of indoor temperature on the cognitive performance of older adults, highlighting the need for optimal indoor climates for mental clarity.

Key Points

  • A study showed that cognitive performance in older adults is enhanced at temperatures between 20-24°C (68-75°F).
  • Variations of as little as 4°C (7°F) can significantly affect attention abilities.
  • Both hot and cold environments hinder focus, but cold temperatures have a more profound negative effect.
  • Older adults often struggle with temperature regulation due to physiological changes.
  • Public health interventions are needed to ensure older adults have access to temperature-controlled environments.

Notable Quotes

Dr. Amir Baniassadi stated, “With global temperatures rising, ensuring access to temperature-controlled environments will be crucial for protecting older adults’ cognitive well-being.”

Conclusion

The findings emphasize that maintaining optimal indoor temperatures is vital for the cognitive health of older adults, calling for community awareness and affordable solutions.

item.title: Sierra Leone declares emergency after confirming second Mpox case in four days - CNBCTV18
item.description:
Sierra Leone Declares Emergency After Second Mpox Case in Four Days

Date: January 13, 2024 | Source: CNBC TV18

Sierra Leone has declared a state of emergency after confirming its second case of Mpox within four days, as health authorities express concern over the rapid spread of the disease.

  • The first case involved recent travel to the northern Port Loko District.
  • Both patients are currently receiving treatment in Freetown.
  • Mpox was first identified in 1958, historically affecting mostly people in central and West Africa.
  • In 2022, Mpox was confirmed to spread through sexual intercourse, leading to outbreaks in over 70 countries.
  • Sierra Leone was previously the epicentre of the 2014 Ebola outbreak, resulting in significant loss of life and healthcare workforce.
"The Congo has borne the brunt of the epidemic, with a vast majority of the roughly 43,000 suspected cases and 1,000 deaths in Africa this year."

This situation poses a significant public health challenge, especially in the context of Sierra Leone's past experiences with epidemics.

item.title: Sores in genital areas? This could be a sign of Herpes virus - The Times of India
item.description:
Sores in genital areas? This could be a sign of Herpes virus

Publication Date: N/A | Source: N/A

This article discusses the indications and implications of herpes simplex virus (HSV), highlighting symptoms, causes, and prevention strategies.

  • Herpes simplex virus causes sores in oral and genital areas.
  • Genital herpes is an STI; 1 in 5 women aged 14-49 are affected.
  • 67% of the global population under age 50 is at risk of HSV.
  • Risk factors include unprotected sex and multiple partners.
  • Early detection through various testing methods improves treatment outcomes.
  • Prevention includes abstinence, condom use, and maintaining hygiene during outbreaks.
“The common risk factors include sexual contact with someone infected with hsv-1 or hsv-2...” - Dr. Archana Dhawan Bajaj

Understanding and preventing herpes involves knowledge about its symptoms, responsible sexual practices, and timely medical intervention.

item.title: Retinal Vascular Analysis: Eye's retina can indicate risk of stroke without lab tests, study suggests - ETHealthWorld
item.description:
Eye's retina can indicate risk of stroke without lab tests, study suggests

Published On Jan 14, 2025 by PTI

New research suggests that blood vessels in the eye's retina can predict stroke risk as accurately as traditional methods without the need for invasive lab tests. This study introduces the concept of a 'vascular fingerprint', which includes 29 indicators of blood vessel health.

  • Researchers analyzed fundus images from 68,753 individuals.
  • Findings show over 10 per cent increased stroke risk associated with changes in blood vessel density and caliber.
  • The study highlights the suitability for implementation in primary healthcare.
"Retinal vascular analysis, a non-invasive screening approach for stroke risk assessment, performed better than traditional risk stratification models," the authors wrote.

This innovative approach potentially revolutionizes how stroke risks can be assessed, particularly in low-resource settings.

item.title: Letting your dog lick your face can be dangerous: Study reveals potential health risk - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Is your dog in the habit of licking your face? Study reveals how this may be dangerous for you.

Date: Jan 14, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

Many pet owners may not realize that allowing their dogs to lick their faces can pose significant health risks. A study from Pennsylvania State University highlights that household dogs can carry antibiotic-resistant strains of Salmonella.

  • Dogs may appear healthy but can carry harmful bacteria.
  • The study found 82 types of Salmonella in dogs examined from 2017 to 2023.
  • 39% of healthy dogs carry a gene (shdA) allowing them to harbor bacteria.
  • Humans can be exposed to Salmonella through saliva when dogs lick their faces.
“This reminds us that simple hygiene practices such as hand washing are needed to protect both our furry friends and ourselves.” - Nkuchia M’ikanatha

Researchers emphasize maintaining good hygiene after interacting with dogs and advise pet owners to avoid kissing their dogs on the lips or allowing them to lick their faces.

item.title: Eye’s retina offers non-invasive stroke risk prediction: study - BusinessLine
item.description:
Eye’s Retina Offers Non-Invasive Stroke Risk Prediction: Study

Publication Date: January 14, 2025 | Source: The Hindu Business Line

Blood vessels in the eye's retina can help predict the risk of stroke as accurately as known risk factors, without requiring invasive lab tests, according to a recent study.

  • The study analyzed 68,753 fundus images to identify 29 retinal health indicators.
  • Nearly 750 strokes were reported over an average follow-up period of 12.5 years.
  • Identified a 'vascular fingerprint' that correlates with stroke risk.
  • More than half of the indicators relate to the density of blood vessels.
  • Non-invasive retinal analysis outperformed traditional risk assessment models.
“Retinal vascular analysis, a non-invasive screening approach for stroke risk assessment, performed better than traditional risk stratification models.”

This innovative approach could transform how stroke risk is assessed, especially in primary healthcare and resource-limited settings.

item.title: Comparative analysis of C-Reactive protein levels among Non-comorbid, Comorbid, and Multimorbid Hospitalized COVID-19 patients - BMC Infectious Diseases
item.description:
Comparative analysis of C-Reactive protein levels among Non-comorbid, Comorbid, and Multimorbid Hospitalized COVID-19 patients

Published: 14 January 2025 | Source: BMC Infectious Diseases

This research evaluates serum C-reactive protein (CRP) levels in different categories of hospitalized COVID-19 patients to understand how comorbidities influence inflammation and disease severity.

  • 618 hospitalized COVID-19 patients analyzed, with varying comorbidity status.
  • Patients with diabetes and hypertension exhibited significantly higher CRP levels.
  • CRP levels averaged 88.92 mg/L, with significant variations observed among age groups and comorbidities.
  • Cox regression analysis indicated that each 1-unit increase in CRP levels correlated with a greater length of hospital stay.
“Elevated CRP levels in COVID-19 patients with comorbidities were strongly associated with increased disease severity.”

This study highlights the importance of monitoring CRP as a biomarker in managing COVID-19, especially among patients with underlying health issues.

item.title: 9 Quick Brain Exercises To Improve Memory And Concentration - Times Now
item.description:
9 Quick Brain Exercises To Improve Memory And Concentration

Date: Jan 14, 2025

Source: Times Now

This article presents nine effective brain exercises to enhance memory and concentration, highlighting their importance for cognitive health.

  • Mindful Breathing: Spend 5-10 minutes focusing on your breath to reduce stress.
  • Daily Memory Recall: Recall 5-10 things you did each day to strengthen short-term memory.
  • Practice Meditation: Engage in daily meditation for improved focus and reduced distractions.
  • Sudoku or Puzzle Games: Boost problem-solving skills with brain games.
  • Physical Exercise: Regular exercise enhances memory and overall brain health.
  • Mental Math: Practice arithmetic in your head to sharpen concentration.
  • Visualization: Spend 5 minutes visualizing a scene or concept to reinforce memory.
  • Active Listening: Focus completely on conversations to enhance memory retention.
  • Sleep Well: Aim for 7-9 hours of quality sleep to support memory consolidation.
"Here are nine daily exercises you should do every day to boost memory and concentration."

Incorporating these exercises into your daily routine can significantly improve cognitive functions and overall brain health.
